entry.title: [blink-dev] Intend to Extend Experiment: Rewriter API
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intend to Extend Experiment: Rewriter API
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intend+to+Extend+Experiment%5C%3A+Rewriter+API%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intend to Extend Experiment: Rewriter API</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Deepti+Bogadi%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Deepti Bogadi</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251022" rel="nofollow">Wed, 22 Oct 2025 11:18:56 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails
<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="244f414a4e4d46454c0a0a0a64474c564b494d51490a4b5643">[email protected]</a>, <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="1a773434345a7972687577736f773475687d">[email protected]</a>,<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="b4d59a9a9af4d7dcc6dbd9ddc1d99adbc6d3">[email protected]</a></pre><pre>
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md</a>
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://webmachinelearning.github.io/writing-assistance-apis/#rewriter-api">https://webmachinelearning.github.io/writing-assistance-apis/#rewriter-api</a>
Summary
The Rewriter API transforms and rephrases input text in requested ways, backed by an on-device AI language model. Developers may use this API to remove redundancies within a text in order to fit into a word limit, rephrase messages to suit the intended audience or to be more constructive if a message is found to use toxic language, rephrasing a post or article to use simpler words and concepts and more. An enterprise policy (GenAILocalFoundationalModelSettings) is available to disable the underlying model downloading which will render the API unavailable.
Blink component
Blink > AI > Writing Assistance <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%20%3E%20AI%20%3E%20Writing%20Assistance%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%20%3E%20AI%20%3E%20Writing%20Assistance%22</a>>
Web Feature ID
No information provided
TAG review
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/991">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/991</a>
TAG review status
Pending
Origin Trial Name
Rewriter API
Chromium Trial Name
AIRewriterAPI
Origin Trial documentation link
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/webmachinelearning/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md#rewriter-api">https://github.com/webmachinelearning/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md#rewriter-api</a>
WebFeature UseCounter name
Rewriter_Create
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
This feature has definite interoperability and compatibility risks, due to the likelihood that different implementations will use different language models, prompts, and fine-tunings, and even within a single implementation such as Chrome, these pieces will likely change over time. Additionally, not all browsers and operating systems will have a built-in language model to expose, and not all devices will be powerful enough to run one effectively. We are taking a variety of steps to attempt to mitigate these risks. For example, the specification is designed to allow the API to be backed by a cloud-based language model. This approach could extend the functionality to a wider range of devices and users. The API is designed to abstract away the specifics of the underlying language model, including prompts and fine-tuning. This prevents developers from relying on specific outputs, ensuring they receive rewritten text rather than structured data that might vary across implementations. Finally, the API surface is designed with many clear points of failure, that encourage the developer to probe for capabilities ahead of time and fall back to other techniques if a capability is not available. Nevertheless, interoperability and compatibility risk remains high for these sorts of APIs, and we'll be closely monitoring it during the experiment period.
Gecko: Negative (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1067">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1067</a>)
WebKit: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/393">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/393</a>)
Web developers: Mixed signals (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/proposals/issues/163">https://github.com/WICG/proposals/issues/163</a>) Prototyping with partners behind a flag revealed enthusiasm and many prototypes built, from which we drew the discussion of potential use cases [1]. Feedback on the WICG thread was more mixed. Some themes we saw include: asking for more capabilities (e.g. full prompting of a language model instead of higher-level APIs (our response at [2]); multi-modal support); desire to make sure the API actually works robustly in many real-world use cases; removal of any safety/ethical safeguards; and confusion about client-side vs. cloud APIs. [1]: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md#summarizer-api">https://github.com/WICG/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md#summarizer-api</a> [2]: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md#directly-exposing-a-prompt-api">https://github.com/WICG/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md#directly-exposing-a-prompt-api</a>
Other signals:
Activation
This feature would definitely benefit from having polyfills, backed by any of: cloud services, lazily-loaded client-side models using WebGPU, or the web developer's own server. We anticipate seeing an ecosystem of such polyfills grow as more developers experiment with this API.
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
No information provided
Goals for experimentation
Although developers have prototyped using the behind-a-flag implementation and given good feedback, several partners are interested in testing out the API with real users. We're looking forward to getting feedback from such testing, especially with regards to output quality, multilingual support, and what types of input data are handled well vs. poorly. We also want to understand whether we've found the right set of options to offer to control the output, and whether the resulting output reflects those controls to the extent that developers expect.
Reason this experiment is being extended
Rewriter API suffers from perceived quality issues and a critical language support disconnect. These APIs are currently not production-ready for many use cases, particularly those outside of English. In addition, we are also seeing low adoption in the OT phase for this API. Hence, we are requesting the extension of the trial to give us time to collect more feedback from our partners and make the API more robust and resilient.
Ongoing technical constraints
As discussed above, not all devices are capable of running the language models required to implement this API. The availability() function allows developers to feature-detect whether the current device can support the API.
Debuggability
It is possible that giving DevTools more insight into the nondeterministic states of the model, e.g. random seeds, could help with debugging. See related discussion at <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/prompt-api/issues/9">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/prompt-api/issues/9</a>.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
No
Not all platforms will come with a language model. In particular, in the initial stages we are focusing on Windows, Mac, and Linux.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ?
No
The API surface is reasonably well tested with mocked models, but production model downloading and non-deterministic outputs are not fully tested at the web-platform-tests layer. The explainer discusses this in <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md#specifications-and-tests">https://github.com/WICG/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md#specifications-and-tests</a> .
DevTrial instructions
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1v6-fOC13zS3S-bOLuqIRbzgmia_aPGJl-wzOx4ItSVE/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1v6-fOC13zS3S-bOLuqIRbzgmia_aPGJl-wzOx4ItSVE/edit?usp=sharing</a>
Flag name on about://flags
rewriter-api-for-gemini-nano
Finch feature name
AIRewriterAPI
Requires code in //chrome?
True
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/358214322">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/358214322</a>
Launch bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4396842">https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4396842</a>
Non-OSS dependencies
Does the feature depend on any code or APIs outside the Chromium open source repository and its open-source dependencies to function?
Yes: this feature depends on a language model, which is bridged to the open-source parts of the implementation via the interfaces in //services/on_device_model.
Estimated milestones
Origin trial desktop first
137
Origin trial desktop last
142
Origin trial extension 1 end milestone
148
DevTrial on desktop
129
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).
At this point all known proposed changes have been incorporated into the specification and implementation.
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5112320150470656?gate=5133588907556864">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5112320150470656?gate=5133588907556864</a>
Links to previous Intent discussions
Intent to Prototype: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAM0wra9Jhe7o59mX5tJPD%3DcZQb2oL3mNi-T57wA86fPXn55OPw%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAM0wra9Jhe7o59mX5tJPD%3DcZQb2oL3mNi-T57wA86fPXn55OPw%40mail.gmail.com</a>
Intent to Experiment: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAM0wra8dnNHXKM26MvQxZ6LBE16PUbvH6-GH5B3Z2WDv4uH0WQ%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAM0wra8dnNHXKM26MvQxZ6LBE16PUbvH6-GH5B3Z2WDv4uH0WQ%40mail.gmail.com</a>
This intent message was generated by Chrome Platform Status <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/">https://chromestatus.com/</a>>.
-- You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="89ebe5e0e7e2a4edecffa2fce7fafcebfaeafba7a7a7c9eae1fbe6e4e0fce4a7e6fbee">[email protected]</a>. To view this discussion visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAJcT_ZhWFB%3DBDdr9S122hbfK0m-77sDcMf9Qufgx4vxDZ4yPZQ%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAJcT_ZhWFB%3DBDdr9S122hbfK0m-77sDcMf9Qufgx4vxDZ4yPZQ%40mail.gmail.com</a>. </pre>
</div>

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Extend Experiment : Writer API
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Extend Experiment : Writer API
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Extend+Experiment+%5C%3A+Writer+API%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Extend Experiment : Writer API</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Deepti+Bogadi%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Deepti Bogadi</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251022" rel="nofollow">Wed, 22 Oct 2025 11:17:36 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails
<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="ef848a8185868d8e87c1c1c1af8c879d8082869a82c1809d88">[email protected]</a>, <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="4e236060600e2d263c2123273b2360213c29">[email protected]</a>, <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="0a6b2424244a6962786567637f672465786d">[email protected]</a></pre><pre>
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md</a>
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://webmachinelearning.github.io/writing-assistance-apis/#writer-api">https://webmachinelearning.github.io/writing-assistance-apis/#writer-api</a>
Summary
The Writer API can be used for writing new material given a writing task prompt, backed by an on-device AI language model. Developers will be able to use this API to generate textual explanations of structured data, composing a post about a product based on reviews or product description, expanding on pro and con lists into full views and more. An enterprise policy (GenAILocalFoundationalModelSettings) is available to disable the underlying model downloading which will render the API unavailable.
Blink component
Blink > AI > Writing Assistance <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%20%3E%20AI%20%3E%20Writing%20Assistance%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%20%3E%20AI%20%3E%20Writing%20Assistance%22</a>>
Web Feature ID
No information provided
TAG review
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/991">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/991</a>
TAG review status
Pending
Origin Trial Name
Writer API
Chromium Trial Name
AIWriterAPI
Origin Trial documentation link
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/webmachinelearning/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md#writer-api">https://github.com/webmachinelearning/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md#writer-api</a>
WebFeature UseCounter name
Writer_Create
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
This feature has definite interoperability and compatibility risks, due to the likelihood that different implementations will use different language models, prompts, and fine-tunings, and even within a single implementation such as Chrome, these pieces will likely change over time. Additionally, not all browsers and operating systems will have a built-in language model to expose, and not all devices will be powerful enough to run one effectively. We are taking a variety of steps to attempt to mitigate these risks. For example, the specification is designed to allow the API to be backed by a cloud-based language model. This approach could extend the functionality to a wider range of devices and users. The API is designed to abstract away the specifics of the underlying language model, including prompts and fine-tuning. This prevents developers from relying on specific outputs, ensuring they receive newly-written text rather than structured data that might vary across implementations. Finally, the API surface is designed with many clear points of failure, that encourage the developer to probe for capabilities ahead of time and fall back to other techniques if a capability is not available. Nevertheless, interoperability and compatibility risk remains high for these sorts of APIs, and we'll be closely monitoring it during the experiment period.
Gecko: Negative (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1067">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1067</a>)
WebKit: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/393">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/393</a>)
Web developers: Mixed signals (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/proposals/issues/163">https://github.com/WICG/proposals/issues/163</a>) Prototyping with partners behind a flag revealed enthusiasm and many prototypes built, from which we drew the discussion of potential use cases [1]. Feedback on the WICG thread was more mixed. Some themes we saw include: asking for more capabilities (e.g. full prompting of a language model instead of higher-level APIs (our response at [2]); multi-modal support); desire to make sure the API actually works robustly in many real-world use cases; removal of any safety/ethical safeguards; and confusion about client-side vs. cloud APIs. [1]: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md#summarizer-api">https://github.com/WICG/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md#summarizer-api</a> [2]: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md#directly-exposing-a-prompt-api">https://github.com/WICG/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md#directly-exposing-a-prompt-api</a>
Other signals:
Activation
This feature would definitely benefit from having polyfills, backed by any of: cloud services, lazily-loaded client-side models using WebGPU, or the web developer's own server. We anticipate seeing an ecosystem of such polyfills grow as more developers experiment with this API.
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
No information provided
Goals for experimentation
Although developers have prototyped using the behind-a-flag implementation and given good feedback, several partners are interested in testing out the API with real users. We're looking forward to getting feedback from such testing, especially with regards to output quality, multilingual support, and what types of writing tasks are handled well vs. poorly. We also want to understand whether we've found the right set of options to offer to control the output, and whether the resulting output reflects those controls to the extent that developers expect.
Reason this experiment is being extended
Writer API suffers from perceived quality issues and a critical language support disconnect. These APIs are currently not production-ready for many use cases, particularly those outside of English. In addition, we are also seeing low adoption in the OT phase for this API. Hence, we are requesting the extension of the trial to give us time to collect more feedback from our partners and make the API more robust and resilient.
Ongoing technical constraints
As discussed above, not all devices are capable of running the language models required to implement this API. The availability() function allows developers to feature-detect whether the current device can support the API.
Debuggability
It is possible that giving DevTools more insight into the nondeterministic states of the model, e.g. random seeds, could help with debugging. See related discussion at <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/prompt-api/issues/9">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/prompt-api/issues/9</a>.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
No
Not all platforms will come with a language model. In particular, in the initial stages we are focusing on Windows, Mac, and Linux.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ?
No
The API surface is reasonably well tested with mocked models, but production model downloading and non-deterministic outputs are not fully tested at the web-platform-tests layer. The explainer discusses this in <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md#specifications-and-tests">https://github.com/WICG/writing-assistance-apis/blob/main/README.md#specifications-and-tests</a> .
DevTrial instructions
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1v6-fOC13zS3S-bOLuqIRbzgmia_aPGJl-wzOx4ItSVE/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1v6-fOC13zS3S-bOLuqIRbzgmia_aPGJl-wzOx4ItSVE/edit?usp=sharing</a>
Flag name on about://flags
writer-api-for-gemini-nano
Finch feature name
AIWriterAPI
Requires code in //chrome?
True
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/357967382">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/357967382</a>
Launch bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4396832">https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4396832</a>
Non-OSS dependencies
Does the feature depend on any code or APIs outside the Chromium open source repository and its open-source dependencies to function?
Yes: this feature depends on a language model, which is bridged to the open-source parts of the implementation via the interfaces in //services/on_device_model.
Estimated milestones
Origin trial desktop first
137
Origin trial desktop last
142
Origin trial extension 1 end milestone
148
DevTrial on desktop
129
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).
At this point all known proposed changes have been incorporated into the specification and implementation.
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/4712595362414592?gate=6282634527375360">https://chromestatus.com/feature/4712595362414592?gate=6282634527375360</a>
Links to previous Intent discussions
Intent to Prototype: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAM0wra9qMAkT%3DiUBbDGfd_zcH7uEqze-H1r5DWUa8OFbtZGZ1Q%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAM0wra9qMAkT%3DiUBbDGfd_zcH7uEqze-H1r5DWUa8OFbtZGZ1Q%40mail.gmail.com</a>
Intent to Experiment: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAM0wra9G-fLtpDFO1%2BdR1JS_1XWgczg%2BRte1_h32FUziSe-yLw%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAM0wra9G-fLtpDFO1%2BdR1JS_1XWgczg%2BRte1_h32FUziSe-yLw%40mail.gmail.com</a>
This intent message was generated by Chrome Platform Status <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/">https://chromestatus.com/</a>>.
-- You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="ef8d83868184c28b8a99c49a819c9a8d9c8c9dc1c1c1af8c879d8082869a82c1809d88">[email protected]</a>. To view this discussion visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAJcT_Zj80nPY9oyPAT29WAXVfeSzUD7UkheafJqjG%2BXi%2BKJtqg%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAJcT_Zj80nPY9oyPAT29WAXVfeSzUD7UkheafJqjG%2BXi%2BKJtqg%40mail.gmail.com</a>. </pre>
</div>

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: FedCM nonce param and error attribute rename

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to ship: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive resources
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to ship: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive resources
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+ship%5C%3A+Cache+sharing+for+extremely%5C-pervasive+resources%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to ship: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive resources</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251022" rel="nofollow">Wed, 22 Oct 2025 08:49:58 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<tt>Thanks for pointing out Mozilla's response. I think they have some fair </tt><tt>points. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>If we look at the list, it is clear from domain names, that some sites, </tt><tt>or entities, will benefit more from others from faster first-loads. I </tt><tt>mean, something like 30% of the list are from Google entities, from very </tt><tt>harmless (IMHO) hosted fonts to analytics, ads and video hosting </tt><tt>(YouTube). Some other big sites like Shopify and Wix/parastorage combine </tt><tt>to another 15%. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre></pre><tt>Having your key resources on that list may not matter very much, or it </tt><tt>may. The existence of the list is scary and I lack the data to </tt><tt>understand what the pros are both in scale and area. Is the disk space </tt><tt>issue a real problem or just something that is a potential concern </tt><tt>lacking investigation, for instance? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>I understand that the published list is not a final, set-in-stone, item, </tt><tt>so I will not comment on individual items, but what thought have there </tt><tt>been on maintaining such a list long term? It seems to me that it might </tt><tt>become an area of contention that would be nice to avoid. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>In the initial intent, the claim was that this is important for the </tt><tt>healthy operation of the web. But is it really? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
/Daniel
On 2025-10-22 15:43, Patrick Meenan wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>FYI, I updated Chromestatus with Mozilla's position on the feature </tt><tt>(strongly negative). It's not a platform-exposed feature but they do </tt><tt>have concerns that they wanted to note in a position issue </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1231">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1231</a>>. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>On Sat, Oct 18, 2025 at 8:34 AM Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="25554840400b0b0b65464d574a484c50480b4a5742">[email protected]</a>> </tt><tt>wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Sorry, I missed a step in making the candidate resource list public. I have moved it to my chromium account and made it public here
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1TgWhdeqKbGm6hLM9WqnnXLn-iiO4Y9HTjDXjVO2aBqI/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1TgWhdeqKbGm6hLM9WqnnXLn-iiO4Y9HTjDXjVO2aBqI/edit?usp=sharing</a>>.
Not everything in that list meets all of the criteria - it's just the first step in the manual curation (same URL served the same content across > 20k sites in the HTTP Archive dataset).
The manual steps frome there for meeting the criteria are basically:
- Cull the list for scripts, stylesheets and compression dictionaries. - Remove any URLs that use query parameters. - Exclude any responses that set cookies. - Identify URLs that are not manually versioned by site embedders (i.e. the embedded resource can not get stale). This is either in-place updating resources or automatically versioned resources. - Only include URLs that can reliably target a single resource by pattern (i.e. ..../<hash>-common.js but not ..../<hash>.js) - Get confirmation from the resource owner that the given URL Pattern is and will continue to be appropriate for the single-keyed cache
On Fri, Oct 17, 2025 at 7:02 PM Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="1e6e737b7b3030305e7d766c7173776b7330716c79">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Assuming we have the privacy and security concerns under control (which we're pretty confident is the case for the extremely small subset of resources we are talking about), the main discussion point is the balancing of incentives and "playing favorites".
As you noted, the performance impact is relatively small but it's not non-zero when you get to the scale of some of the resources we are talking about (like <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.google-analytics.com/analytics.js">https://www.google-analytics.com/analytics.js</a> which is on 10M of the pages in the 50M page HTTP Archive dataset). This isn't really a framework discussion because those kinds of resources aren't a good fit for the restrictions that are in place for the privacy and security protections but there is a discussion about providing network benefits to specific third-parties that cross the pervasive threshold and meet the rest of the conditions (for at least part of the library).
The question is if the marginal performance benefit that can only be realized at that level of scale (where a given user would be likely to have the current version of that specific library in cache) would be a meaningful competitive factor for a newcomer (vs features, ease of use, pricing, mindshare, etc).
That also gets balanced against the user benefit of not having to keep re-downloading the exact same thing and from having to keep dozens of copies of it in cache, cached with different cache keys (taking cache space away from other resources).
There's also a more nuanced benefit that allows for federation of a feature across domains vs centralizing the experience. For example, Shopify and Wix's platform libraries show up in the candidate list as they are used by hundreds of thousands of sites in the CrUX dataset. Having a shared cache for those libraries would put them into a more competitive position against centralized platforms (Amazon, Etsy, Blogger, etc) while still allowing sites to own the overall experience.
I guess that's the long way of saying "it's complicated but we feel pretty strongly that the theoretical risk in this case is more than offset by the platform benefits".
On Fri, Oct 17, 2025 at 5:15 PM Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="ea9a878f8fc4c4c4aa8982988587839f87c485988d">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Nothing is being pre-populated (other than the list of URL patterns). When a "pervasive" resource is encountered naturally by a given user, it will be stored in a single-keyed cache instead of a site/frame/url-keyed cache (reducing storage duplication for that specific resource for that specific user).
The linked doc has all of the mitigations in place, but the big one for explicit tracking is that it can only be used when full cookie access is also allowed, otherwise it falls through to the fully-partitioned cache.
On Fri, Oct 17, 2025 at 4:58 PM Alex Russell <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="12617e7b757a667e6b3c3c3c52717a607d7f7b677f3c7d6075">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
This is interesting, given all of the problems involved in governance and the way it cuts against platform progress <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://infrequently.org/2022/03/cache-and-prizes/">https://infrequently.org/2022/03/cache-and-prizes/</a>>. Will the full set be downloaded before any pre-population is used? What controls will be in place to make sure that this does not exacerbate cross-site tracking via timing? Will these caches be pushed in a versioned way? Who will make the call about how much can be in the set? And are these delivered via component-updater?
Best,
Alex
On Friday, October 17, 2025 at 1:44:19 PM UTC-7 Patrick Meenan wrote:
I expect it will change over time but the changes should be pretty minor (as new resources increase or decrease popularity). Generally we'd want to include resources that have been common for a while and are likely to continue to be common. I'd expect small changes every milestone (or two). There's also the <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="4c3c293e3a2d3f253a29612f2d6262620c2f243e232125392162233e2b">[email protected]</a> mailing list that you can ping to give us a heads-up (or a CL to Chromium) if there's something specific you want to draw attention to.
On Fri, Oct 17, 2025 at 4:33 PM Ben Kelly <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="483f29262c2d3a3e66666608252d3c29662b2725">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Thank you. Do you expect the list of resources to change over time? Will http archive data be analyzed for every milestone release?
*From: *Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="6f1f020a0a4141412f0c071d0002061a0241001d08">[email protected]</a>> *Date: *Friday, October 17, 2025 at 4:30 PM *To: *Ben Kelly <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="cabdaba4aeafb8bce4e4e48aa7afbeabe4a9a5a7">[email protected]</a>> *Cc: *blink-dev <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="1e7c72777075337a7b685e7d766c7173776b7330716c79">[email protected]</a>> *Subject: *Re: [blink-dev] Intent to ship: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive resources
This Message Is From an External Sender Yes. The list will be committed directly to the Chromium repository. The list of candidate resources (before the manual vetting) is in a sheet here
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1hXYVqwHQJJVTJ3LnKwMZiGF-eFGHc1J8y8k3Xc7h8zc/edit?usp=sharing__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!5dVWGFYASzLWqT-IVHrc7lq1pVJyQ3AMs4O-AkEt6daUAkc_lPuOdm000ap-M0eOLyAF5EjjHFZsGcbwoQ$">https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1hXYVqwHQJJVTJ3LnKwMZiGF-eFGHc1J8y8k3Xc7h8zc/edit?usp=sharing__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!5dVWGFYASzLWqT-IVHrc7lq1pVJyQ3AMs4O-AkEt6daUAkc_lPuOdm000ap-M0eOLyAF5EjjHFZsGcbwoQ$</a>>.
On Fri, Oct 17, 2025 at 4:15 PM Ben Kelly <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="89fee8e7edecfbffa7a7a7c9e4ecfde8a7eae6e4">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Will the list of manually curated scripts be published somewhere? I did not immediately see something like this skimming the doc or chrome status entry.
Thanks.
Ben
*From: *Patrick Meenan <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="d2a2bfb7b7fcfcfc92b1baa0bdbfbba7bffcbda0b5">[email protected]</a>> *Date: *Friday, October 17, 2025 at 3:12 PM *To: *blink-dev <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="c5a7a9acabaee8a1a0b385a6adb7aaa8acb0a8ebaab7a2">[email protected]</a>> *Subject: *[blink-dev] Intent to ship: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive resources
This Message Is From an External Sender *Contact emails* <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="6c1c0109094242422c0f041e030105190142031e0b">[email protected]</a>
*Specification* /N/A/
*Design docs*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?usp=sharing</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?usp=sharing__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!-6GuUS4M8m3Eym1K4Y1Vts7sGxQ5HhifoRFNweoIoUZ-dzRbuYLifuL-fX5yWDeuNmOQnc25VJhFCuXRtQ$">https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?usp=sharing__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!-6GuUS4M8m3Eym1K4Y1Vts7sGxQ5HhifoRFNweoIoUZ-dzRbuYLifuL-fX5yWDeuNmOQnc25VJhFCuXRtQ$</a>>
*Summary* For a small number (hundreds) of hand-curated static third-party script, stylesheet and compression-dictionary resources that are used on a large portion of the web, Chrome will use a single-keyed HTTP cache to store those resources.
This helps users and site owners with faster performance for those resources that are very widely used while maintaining the privacy protections of the partitioned disk cache. This feature targets the resources that most users are likely to see multiple times across multiple sites in any given browsing session. They are usually not in the critical path of the page loading and may not impact the common performance metrics but they are still important for the healthy operation of the web.
The list of candidate resources is manually curated from the HTTP Archive dataset and updated on an ongoing basis. This includes site-independent things like common analytics scripts, social media embeds, video player embeds, captcha providers and ads libraries.
It allows for code that uses versioned URLs as long as the versioning is not a manual process by embedders and that the same version is sent to everybody at a given point in time with the same contents. This does not include things like common Javascript libraries where they are commonly self-hosted or where the URL references a specific version of the library and it is up to site owners to manually select a version.
i.e.
Yes:
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://maps.googleapis.com/maps-api-v3/api/js/62/5d/common.js">https://maps.googleapis.com/maps-api-v3/api/js/62/5d/common.js</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://maps.googleapis.com/maps-api-v3/api/js/62/5d/common.js__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!-6GuUS4M8m3Eym1K4Y1Vts7sGxQ5HhifoRFNweoIoUZ-dzRbuYLifuL-fX5yWDeuNmOQnc25VJgSqmyqgQ$">https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://maps.googleapis.com/maps-api-v3/api/js/62/5d/common.js__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!-6GuUS4M8m3Eym1K4Y1Vts7sGxQ5HhifoRFNweoIoUZ-dzRbuYLifuL-fX5yWDeuNmOQnc25VJgSqmyqgQ$</a>> No:
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.5.1/jquery.min.js">https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.5.1/jquery.min.js</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.5.1/jquery.min.js__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!-6GuUS4M8m3Eym1K4Y1Vts7sGxQ5HhifoRFNweoIoUZ-dzRbuYLifuL-fX5yWDeuNmOQnc25VJj4u2iLCA$">https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.5.1/jquery.min.js__;!!Bt8RZUm9aw!-6GuUS4M8m3Eym1K4Y1Vts7sGxQ5HhifoRFNweoIoUZ-dzRbuYLifuL-fX5yWDeuNmOQnc25VJj4u2iLCA$</a>>

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Performance + Event Timing: InteractionCount
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Performance + Event Timing: InteractionCount
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Performance+%5C%2B+Event+Timing%5C%3A+InteractionCount%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Performance + Event Timing: InteractionCount</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251022" rel="nofollow">Wed, 22 Oct 2025 08:41:30 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="264b4b4908080866414949414a430845494b">[email protected]</a> </pre><pre>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#dom-performance-interactioncount">https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#dom-performance-interactioncount</a>
Design docs No information provided <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#dom-performance-interactioncount">https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#dom-performance-interactioncount</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#sec-increasing-interaction-count">https://www.w3.org/TR/event-timing/#sec-increasing-interaction-count</a>
Summary The Event Timing API is part of the Performance Timeline and is used to measure the performance of user interactions. Certain Events will have an interactionId value assigned to them, and this is useful for grouping related interactions based on common physical user inputs or gestures. This feature adds a very trivial performance.interactionCount, which is just the total number of interactions that have occured on the page. In particular, this feature is useful for computing the Interaction to Next Paint (INP) metric value, which requires knowing the total number of interactions in order to compute a high percentile score (p98 for pages with greater than 50 total interactions). This feature has been specced for a long while, was prototypes in Chromium a long time ago but never shipped, is part of Interop 2025, and is already available in other browsers. (Note: there is already a more powerful performance.eventCounts map for specific events, but it is not possible to accurately map event cunts to interaction counts.)
Blink component Blink>PerformanceAPIs
Web Feature ID event-timing
Motivation Used to count the number of important real user interactions with a page. This is distinct from counting the number of events that Event Timing measures (because a single physical user gesture may fire many, variable number, of specific events, depending on the type of input and event target and page design) but you can already count interactions (inconveniently) by just counting the number of unique interactionId values in Event Timing API. Used for calculating Interaction to Next Paint (INP) metric.
Initial public proposal No information provided
TAG review No information provided
TAG review status Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility Other browser venders have already shipped this feature as part of the Interop 2025 effort for CWV INP. The main interop risk is that there are existing polyfills for interactionCount in Chromium for INP calculation. However, popular polyfills (such as web-vitals.js) have long been tested to feature detect, given the long experimental web platform implementation in chromium.
Gecko: Shipped/Shipping (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/mozilla.org/g/dev-platform/c/xvv6sxJZc4U/m/JzSSCoxPAgAJ?e=48417069">https://groups.google.com/a/mozilla.org/g/dev-platform/c/xvv6sxJZc4U/m/JzSSCoxPAgAJ?e=48417069</a>)
WebKit: In development (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=297361">https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=297361</a>)
Web developers: Strongly positive No specific link, but this feature is related to the very popular INP metric definition (and obviates the need for an imperfect polyfill for counting interactions).
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications? n/a
Debuggability DevTools has existing support for Interactions (real time performance monitor and tracing). Visualizing total interactionCount is not needed, but can be easily found (via literally counting the list of interactions, or just console logs).
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? Yes <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/event-timing/">https://wpt.fyi/results/event-timing/</a> (several tests, look for interaction-count-*)
Flag name on about://flags No information provided
Finch feature name EventTimingInteractionCount
Rollout plan Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome? False
Availability expectation Feature is available on Web Platform Baseline within 12 months of launch in Chrome (as part of Interop 2025 for INP)
Adoption expectation Polyfill already widely adopted (for INP calculation), and feature detection already used.
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop 143
DevTrial on desktop 111
Shipping on Android 143
DevTrial on Android 111
Shipping on WebView 143
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (eg links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (eg, changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). Already specced in Event Timing API.
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5153386492198912?gate=5819984274128896">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5153386492198912?gate=5819984274128896</a>
This intent message was generated by Chrome Platform Status.
-- You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="66040a0f080d4b0203104d130815130415051448484826050e14090b0f130b48091401">[email protected]</a>. To view this discussion visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/68f8fb21.050a0220.39dfc1.1a8d.GAE%40google.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/68f8fb21.050a0220.39dfc1.1a8d.GAE%40google.com</a>. </pre>
</div>

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: WebTransport Application Protocol Negotiation
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: WebTransport Application Protocol Negotiation
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+WebTransport+Application+Protocol+Negotiation%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: WebTransport Application Protocol Negotiation</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251022" rel="nofollow">Wed, 22 Oct 2025 08:04:42 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM2
On 10/15/25 10:46 a.m., Rick Byers wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>Thanks for the explainer. This seems like a small and clearly </tt><tt>beneficial extension to WebTransport to me without any red flags. LGTM1 </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre></pre><tt>On Tue, Oct 14, 2025 at 5:33 PM 'Victor Vasiliev' via blink-dev </tt><tt><<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="30525c595e5b1d545546705358425f5d59455d1e5f4257">[email protected]</a>> wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Hi Alex,
Sorry for the late reply; I've been travelling/OOO for a couple of weeks.
The explainer is at
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/webtransport/blob/main/explainers/subprotocol_negotiation.md">https://github.com/w3c/webtransport/blob/main/explainers/subprotocol_negotiation.md</a>>.
Thanks, Victor.
On Wed, Sep 24, 2025 at 11:13 AM Alex Russell <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="bdced1d4dad5c9d1c4939393fdded5cfd2d0d4c8d093d2cfda">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Hey Victor,
I appreciate you taking the time to outline this here. I have some background on Web Transport (was co-TL for Project Fugu), but it would be great for this to be in a separate Explainer document using the usual template, as it isn't clear what we're winning, which applications this enables, and how it actually interacts with ALPN and the other parts of the various handshakes involved. Our overriding question from the API OWNERS perspective is "/does this problem solve an important problem well?/".
When we're the leading implementation on a feature (which is the usual case these days), we need to provide some arguments and evidence that the use-cases are meaningful to developers, and input from developers about how this is necessary and useful to them. Explainers provide a format for structuring those arguments and explaining the motivating use-cases.
Thanks again,
Alex
On Tuesday, September 23, 2025 at 3:10:54 AM UTC-7 Victor Vasiliev wrote:
Hi Alex,
WebTransport provides web developers with a networking abstraction that is semantically similar to having a QUIC connection; because of that, all of the user data within a WebTransport session is sent on independent data streams that may arrive in arbitrary order.
Normally, this is to the advantage of the applications that are built on top of QUIC or WebTransport. However, one thing that applications often want to do is negotiate the protocol version at the start; in the multistream world, this is difficult, since you don't know upfront which stream actually has the version negotiation info (they can arrive out of order).
Protocols that are built on top of QUIC directly solve this problem by negotiating versions inside the handshake that happens before any actual application data is exchanged, using a mechanism called TLS ALPN (this actually works for TCP too, this is how a Web server can, for instance, support HTTP/1.1 and HTTP/2 at the same TCP port). The feature in question adds a similar mechanism to WebTransport, by performing an ALPN-like negotiation inside the WebTransport handshake.
Thanks, Victor.
On Mon, Sep 22, 2025 at 2:49 PM Alex Russell <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="8af9e6e3ede2fee6f3a4a4a4cae9e2f8e5e7e3ffe7a4e5f8ed">[email protected]</a>> wrote:
Hey Victor,
As there's no explainer, can you outline what the use-cases for protocol negotiation are? The linked part of the spec does not provide clarity as to why this is valuable, who it's valuable to, or why we should support it. That is, we are always trying to understand "/does this feature solve an important problem well?/" it isn't clear (yet) in this case.
Best,
Alex
On Monday, September 22, 2025 at 12:38:46 AM UTC-7 Chromestatus wrote:
*Contact emails* <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="dcaabdafb5f2f2f29cbfb4aeb3b1b5a9b1f2b3aebb">[email protected]</a>
*Explainer* None
*Specification*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://w3c.github.io/webtransport/#dom-webtransportoptions-protocols">https://w3c.github.io/webtransport/#dom-webtransportoptions-protocols</a>
*Summary* WebTransport Application Protocol Negotiation allows negotiation of the protocol used by the web application within the WebTransport handshake. A web application can specify a list of application protocols offered when constructing a WebTransport object, which are then conveyed to the server via HTTP headers; if the server picks one of those protocols, it can indicate that within response headers, and that reply is available within the WebTransport object.
*Blink component* Blink>Network>WebTransport
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ENetwork%3EWebTransport%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ENetwork%3EWebTransport%22</a>>
*Web Feature ID* webtransport <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://webstatus.dev/features/webtransport">https://webstatus.dev/features/webtransport</a>>
*TAG review* None
*TAG review status* Not applicable
*Risks*
*Interoperability and Compatibility* The feature was designed to work cleanly with existing servers that do not support protocol negotiation. If the server does not support application protocol negotiation, or does not accept any of the protocols offered, the API will return null as the selected protocol.
/Gecko/: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/167">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/167</a>) Firefox has been positive on WebTransport, and Mozilla representatives have been involved in the discussion regarding this flag (and have told me in the past that I don't need to file new standards position for every spec feature).
/WebKit/: Support (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/18">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/18</a>) Safari has expressed support for WebTransport in general; we've not reached out regarding this individual feature, given that Safari has not shipped WebTransport itself.
/Web developers/: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/moq-wg/moq-transport/pull/499">https://github.com/moq-wg/moq-transport/pull/499</a>) IETF MOQ relies on this feature for version negotiation; I've been repeatedly pinged by multiple people there asking when Chrome is going to ship this.
/Other signals/:
*WebView application risks*
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications? None
*Debuggability* Since the negotiation is done via HTTP headers, those should be visible through DevTools.
*Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?* Yes
*Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?*
Yes<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/webtransport/connect.https.any.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/webtransport/connect.https.any.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/webtransport/connect.https.any.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/webtransport/connect.https.any.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>>
*Flag name on about://flags* None
*Finch feature name* WebTransportApplicationProtocol
*Rollout plan* Will ship enabled for all users
*Requires code in //chrome?* False
*Tracking bug* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/u/1/issues/416080492">https://issues.chromium.org/u/1/issues/416080492</a>
*Estimated milestones* Shipping on desktop 142 Shipping on Android 142
*Anticipated spec changes*
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). None
*Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/6521719678042112?gate=4663773843161088">https://chromestatus.com/feature/6521719678042112?gate=4663773843161088</a>
This intent message was generated by Chrome Platform Status <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com">https://chromestatus.com</a>>.

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS color space display-p3-linear
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS color space display-p3-linear
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+CSS+color+space+display%5C-p3%5C-linear%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS color space display-p3-linear</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251022" rel="nofollow">Wed, 22 Oct 2025 06:06:57 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<tt>The page at </tt><tt><a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.chromium.org/blink/guidelines/web-platform-changes-guidelines">https://www.chromium.org/blink/guidelines/web-platform-changes-guidelines</a> </tt><tt>lists most of the things we want to know before sending a feature out </tt><tt>into the wild wild world. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>One of the main questions regards compatibility. We want what we do to </tt><tt>end up in a web where browsers agree on how something should be rendered </tt><tt>which is why we typically require new features to probe Mozilla and </tt><tt>WebKit through their web standards positions (unless they have already </tt><tt>shipped). </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre></pre><tt>Another aspect of compatibility, and risk, is about web compatibility. </tt><tt>Will this change break things? Are we really, really sure? That is why </tt><tt>we typically require every feature to have a finch flag so that at least </tt><tt>Google Chrome can turn off something that causes unexpected problems. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>When I say "typical", it's because no rule fits all, but then we instead </tt><tt>need to know why a certain rule does not apply. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>You will also see that we ask for some info texts, explainer, </tt><tt>specification, that many implementers consider obvious. Often it is not </tt><tt>obvious for other people though, and these texts end up in official blog </tt><tt>posts and in other external communication. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
/Daniel
On 2025-10-22 12:41, Christopher Cameron wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Let me know what questions you have.
</pre><tt>Indeed, almost everything is N/A (I've filled them out in the feature </tt><tt>if you want to look). </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>On Wed, Oct 22, 2025 at 12:20 PM Daniel Bratell <<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="5133233025343d7f7f7f11363c30383d7f323e3c">[email protected]</a>> </tt><tt>wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
The form seems fields seem to be mostly left empty. I don't think anything should be empty (though a N/A may fit some things). I have questions, but they would mostly be answered by filling in the form and re-posting it.
/Daniel
On 2025-10-22 11:58, 'Christopher Cameron' via blink-dev wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Hello blink-dev!
This very simple feature adds display-p3-linear as a CSS color space. This has been added to the CSS specification and has a bazillion WPT tests from: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/12596">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/12596</a> It has been requested as a candidate for interop 2026: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/interop/issues/1167">https://github.com/web-platform-tests/interop/issues/1167</a> * * More relevant to the topics close to my heart are the fact that this is a very good space for physically based rendering and high dynamic range. Adding this space to the list of canvas spaces is a separate feature over at: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5122501071994880">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5122501071994880</a>
*Contact emails* <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="bcdfdfddd1d9929292fcdfd4ced3d1d5c9d192d3cedb">[email protected]</a>
*Specification* /No information provided/
*Summary* Add display-p3-linear CSS color space
*Blink component* Blink>CSS <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22</a>>
*Web Feature ID* color-function <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://webstatus.dev/features/color-function">https://webstatus.dev/features/color-function</a>>
*Motivation* /No information provided/
*Initial public proposal* /No information provided/
*TAG review* /No information provided/
*TAG review status* Not applicable
*Risks*
*Interoperability and Compatibility* /No information provided/
/Gecko/: No signal
/WebKit/: No signal
/Web developers/: No signals
/Other signals/:
*WebView application risks*
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
/No information provided/
*Debuggability* /No information provided/
*Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?* No
*Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?* No
*Flag name on about://flags* /No information provided/
*Finch feature name* /No information provided/
*Non-finch justification* /No information provided/
*Rollout plan* Will ship enabled for all users
*Requires code in //chrome?* False
*Estimated milestones*
No milestones specified
*Anticipated spec changes*
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).
/No information provided/
*Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5162372125818880?gate=4761603400663040">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5162372125818880?gate=4761603400663040</a>
This intent message was generated by Chrome Platform Status <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/">https://chromestatus.com/</a>>. </pre><tt> -- </tt><tt> You received this message because you are subscribed to the </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="4b2927222520662f2e3d603e25383e293828396565650b2823392426223e266524392c">[email protected]</a>. To view this discussion visit
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAGnfxj9fo12y5zfJ_TosXUU6LaQ6CAcRSX6nqBGnMUWvHZST9w%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAGnfxj9fo12y5zfJ_TosXUU6LaQ6CAcRSX6nqBGnMUWvHZST9w%40mail.gmail.com</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAGnfxj9fo12y5zfJ_TosXUU6LaQ6CAcRSX6nqBGnMUWvHZST9w%40mail.gmail.com?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAGnfxj9fo12y5zfJ_TosXUU6LaQ6CAcRSX6nqBGnMUWvHZST9w%40mail.gmail.com?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer</a>>. </pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;">

To view this discussion visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/7c9fb616-5b30-4aad-a881-5e4cc931d533%40gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/7c9fb616-5b30-4aad-a881-5e4cc931d533%40gmail.com</a>. </pre>

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: RTCDegradationPreference enum value "maintain-framerate-and-resolution"
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: RTCDegradationPreference enum value "maintain-framerate-and-resolution"
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+RTCDegradationPreference+enum+value+%5C%22maintain%5C-framerate%5C-and%5C-resolution%5C%22%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: RTCDegradationPreference enum value "maintain-framerate-and-resolution"</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251022" rel="nofollow">Wed, 22 Oct 2025 04:41:19 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="a6d5d5cfca888888e6c5ced4c9cbcfd3cb88c9d4c1">[email protected]</a> </pre><pre>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/mst-content-hint/#dom-rtcdegradationpreference-maintain-framerate-and-resolution">https://www.w3.org/TR/mst-content-hint/#dom-rtcdegradationpreference-maintain-framerate-and-resolution</a>
Summary "maintain-framerate-and-resolution" disables WebRTC's internal video adaptation. This enables the application to implement its own adaptation logic and prevents interference from the internal adaptation. From <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/mst-content-hint/#dom-rtcdegradationpreference-maintain-framerate-and-resolution:">https://www.w3.org/TR/mst-content-hint/#dom-rtcdegradationpreference-maintain-framerate-and-resolution:</a> Maintain framerate and resolution regardless of video quality. The user agent SHOULD NOT prefer reducing the framerate or resolution for quality and performance reasons, but MAY drop frames before encoding if necessary not to overuse network and encoder resources.
Blink component Blink>WebRTC>PeerConnection
Web Feature ID webrtc
Motivation WebRTC has an internal video adaptation mechanism that optimizes video quality and performance by adjusting encoding settings. This mechanism relies on hardcoded logic and thresholds, which may not yield optimal results across diverse use cases. Application may benefit from implementing and using its own, external adaptation. For the external adaptation to work properly, the internal one needs to be disabled. "maintain-framerate-and-resolution" allows to disable the WebRTC's internal adaptation. WebRTC WG presentation: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/11rr8X4aOao1AmvyoDLX8o9CPCmnDHkWGRM3nB4Q_104/edit?slide=id.g3657813d9b5_0_0#slide=id.g3657813d9b5_0_0">https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/11rr8X4aOao1AmvyoDLX8o9CPCmnDHkWGRM3nB4Q_104/edit?slide=id.g3657813d9b5_0_0#slide=id.g3657813d9b5_0_0</a>
Initial public proposal No information provided
TAG review No information provided
TAG review status Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility No information provided
Gecko: No signal
WebKit: No signal
Web developers: No signals
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications? Low risk. This change adds "maintain-framerate-and-resolution" to the RTCDegradationPreference enum. This new mode will not be used as a default or as a fallback option.
Debuggability No information provided
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? No
Flag name on about://flags No information provided
Finch feature name No information provided
Non-finch justification No information provided
Rollout plan Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome? False
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop 144
Shipping on Android 144
Shipping on WebView 144
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (eg links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (eg, changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). No information provided
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5156290162720768?gate=5857376464928768">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5156290162720768?gate=5857376464928768</a>
This intent message was generated by Chrome Platform Status.
-- You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="b1d3ddd8dfda9cd5d4c79ac4dfc2c4d3c2d2c39f9f9ff1d2d9c3dedcd8c4dc9fdec3d6">[email protected]</a>. To view this discussion visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/68f8c2d6.050a0220.39dfc1.1587.GAE%40google.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/68f8c2d6.050a0220.39dfc1.1587.GAE%40google.com</a>. </pre>
</div>

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS color space display-p3-linear
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS color space display-p3-linear
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+CSS+color+space+display%5C-p3%5C-linear%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS color space display-p3-linear</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27Christopher+Cameron%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'Christopher Cameron' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251022" rel="nofollow">Wed, 22 Oct 2025 02:58:27 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Hello blink-dev!
This very simple feature adds display-p3-linear as a CSS color space. This has been added to the CSS specification and has a bazillion WPT tests from: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/12596">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/12596</a> It has been requested as a candidate for interop 2026: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/interop/issues/1167">https://github.com/web-platform-tests/interop/issues/1167</a></pre><pre>
More relevant to the topics close to my heart are the fact that this is a very good space for physically based rendering and high dynamic range. Adding this space to the list of canvas spaces is a separate feature over at: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5122501071994880">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5122501071994880</a>
*Contact emails* <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="a8cbcbc9c5cd868686e8cbc0dac7c5c1ddc586c7dacf">[email protected]</a>
*Specification* *No information provided*
*Summary* Add display-p3-linear CSS color space
*Blink component* Blink>CSS <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22</a>>
*Web Feature ID* color-function <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://webstatus.dev/features/color-function">https://webstatus.dev/features/color-function</a>>
*Motivation* *No information provided*
*Initial public proposal* *No information provided*
*TAG review* *No information provided*
*TAG review status* Not applicable
*Risks*
*Interoperability and Compatibility* *No information provided*
*Gecko*: No signal
*WebKit*: No signal
*Web developers*: No signals
*Other signals*:
*WebView application risks*
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications? *No information provided*
*Debuggability* *No information provided*
*Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?* No
*Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?* No
*Flag name on about://flags* *No information provided*
*Finch feature name* *No information provided*
*Non-finch justification* *No information provided*
*Rollout plan* Will ship enabled for all users
*Requires code in //chrome?* False
*Estimated milestones*
No milestones specified
*Anticipated spec changes*
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). *No information provided*
*Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status* <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5162372125818880?gate=4761603400663040">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5162372125818880?gate=4761603400663040</a>
This intent message was generated by Chrome Platform Status <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/">https://chromestatus.com/</a>>.
-- You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="2f4d43464144024b4a59045a415c5a4d5c4c5d0101016f4c475d4042465a4201405d48">[email protected]</a>. To view this discussion visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAGnfxj9fo12y5zfJ_TosXUU6LaQ6CAcRSX6nqBGnMUWvHZST9w%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAGnfxj9fo12y5zfJ_TosXUU6LaQ6CAcRSX6nqBGnMUWvHZST9w%40mail.gmail.com</a>. </pre>

entry.title: [blink-dev] Web-Facing Change PSA: CSS letter-spacing and word-spacing: percentage values
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Web-Facing Change PSA: CSS letter-spacing and word-spacing: percentage values
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Web%5C-Facing+Change+PSA%5C%3A+CSS+letter%5C-spacing+and+word%5C-spacing%5C%3A+percentage+values%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Web-Facing Change PSA: CSS letter-spacing and word-spacing: percentage values</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20251022" rel="nofollow">Wed, 22 Oct 2025 01:59:44 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="3c56565d0c041212127c5b515d5550125f5351">[email protected]</a> </pre><pre>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-text-4/#propdef-letter-spacing">https://www.w3.org/TR/css-text-4/#propdef-letter-spacing</a>
Summary Enables percentage values for the letter-spacing and word-spacing CSS property, as defined in the CSS Text Module Level 4 spec. Percentage values are calculated relative to the advance measure of the space character (U+0020). This gives developers more robust and flexible control over typography, particularly in responsive designs where text spacing needs to adapt to different viewports and font sizes.
Blink component Blink>Layout>Inline
Web Feature ID letter-spacing
Search tags letter-spacing, word-spacing
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility Risks are low. This is a support for new value of CSS properties. So sites not using properties won't be affected. Firefox and Safari has supported this feature for years.
Gecko: Shipped/Shipping
WebKit: Shipped/Shipping (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/WebKit/pull/18771">https://github.com/WebKit/WebKit/pull/18771</a>)
Web developers: No signals (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/327740939">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/327740939</a>) The issue has 3 votes.
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications? No information provided
Debuggability No information provided
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? Yes - "letter-spacing-percentage-001.html" file in <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-text/letter-spacing">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-text/letter-spacing</a> - "word-spacing-percentage-001.html" file in <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-text/word-spacing">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-text/word-spacing</a>
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/327740939">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/327740939</a>
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop 143
Shipping on Android 143
Shipping on WebView 143
Shipping on iOS 143
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5074916059381760">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5074916059381760</a>
This intent message was generated by Chrome Platform Status.
